summary: Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) is a rare and aggressive type of breast cancer where cancer cells block lymph vessels in the skin of the breast, causing the breast to become warm, red, and swollen. It often presents with symptoms resembling skin inflammation, such as redness and swelling, and may not be detected by mammography or ultrasound. IBC is characterized by rapid onset of symptoms and is often diagnosed at a later stage.
causes: Cancer cells blocking lymph vessels in the skin of the breast
risk_factors: History of breast cancer or benign breast disease
Reproductive history leading to more estrogen exposure (early menstruation, late first birth, late menopause)
Radiation therapy to the breast or chest
Younger age at diagnosis for African-Americans
symptoms: Scaly, red, or swollen skin in the nipple area or breast
Swelling of lymph nodes (under the arm or in the neck)
Unusual warmth of the affected breast
Breast size may seem to decrease
diagnosis: Staging tests (imaging, sentinel lymph node biopsy)
